chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this exercise, we know about the Series EE bonds offered by the U.S. Treasury and their conditions. With this information, we need to calculate certain values for specific cases.
We know that the Series EE bonds' annual rate of return is 0.10%, however, if you hold the bond for 20 years the U.S. Treasury will return double its face value.

*Case a:*

We want to calculate the rate of return we would earn if we bought a $50 face value bond and we wait the 20 years to earn double of the face value. For that, we are going to use the Present Value (PV) formula and rearrange it to obtain the applied rate. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
PV &= \frac{FV}{(1+r)^t} \\
\\
r& = \sqrt[t]{\frac{FV}{PV}}-1
\end{aligned}$$


*Where:*
- FV is the future value
- r is the applied rate
- t is the periods of time the rate is applied

Having established this, we can proceed to calculate the effective rate. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
r& = \sqrt[20]{\frac{(\$50\cdot2) }{\$50}}-1 \\
\\
& = \boxed{3.53\%}
\end{aligned}$$

The rate of return is **3.53%**.

*Case b:*

In this case, we consider that we bought the bond in 2017 at $50 (face value) and we want to know the value of the bond for the year 2027. We know that the coupon rate is 0.10% per annum.  For this, we are going to use the formula of Future Value (FV). 


$$ \begin{aligned}
FV &= {PV}\cdot{(1+r)^t} \\
\end{aligned}$$

*Where:*
- PV is the present value
- r is the applied rate
- t is the periods of time the rate is applied

First, we need how much time should we account for interest.

$$ \begin{aligned}
t & = 2027 - 2017\\
& = 10
\end{aligned}$$

We need to account for 10 years of interest.

*Case c:*

Considering the value of the last case we decide to keep the bond for the whole 20 years until it doubles its face value in 2037. Having taken that desition we want to know what would be the effective rate of return between those last ten years. For that, we are going to use the Present Value (PV) formula and rearrange it to obtain the applied rate again. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
PV &= \frac{FV}{(1+r)^t} \\
\\
r& = \sqrt[t]{\frac{FV}{PV}}-1
\end{aligned}$$


*Where:*
- FV is the future value
- r is the applied rate
- t is the periods of time the rate is applied
